column3:
AI and the Labor Market

 
Use of artificial intelligence over the next ten years will have a negative impact on the earnings potential of substantial numbers of high-skilled workers in advanced countries.
column4: Confidence in this topic (10 being the highest).
column5: Please explain your response in 280 characters or less.
column6: Use of artificial intelligence over the next ten years will lead to substantially greater uncertainty about the likely returns to investment in education.
column7: Confidence in this topic (10 being the highest).
column8: Please explain your response in 280 characters or less.
column9: Use of artificial intelligence over the next ten years is likely to have a measurable impact in increasing income inequality.
column10: Confidence in this topic (10 being the highest).
column11: Please explain your response in 280 characters or less.

column5: Three major uncertainties. 1. Not clear whether AI will successfully target tasks performed by the highly skilled. Evidence so far shows not. 2. Generative AI can also complement some high skill tasks. 3. Skilled workers can change occupations and shift negative effects to others
column8: Though there is some uncertainty the burden will fall on less educated workers. Social skills will become valuable, and specialized technical skills as well as higher education will most likely remain protected from AI. The flexibility conferred by education will also be valuable
column11: While it is possible for generative AI to be a useful tool for noncollege workers, I do not see the current path achieving this, and the existing evidence is more consistent with most of the burden of displacement falling on less educated, lower-wage workers.

column5: I think this will be a _relative_ effect not an absolute effect. I don't think that AI will make us poorer, and it may not (or it may) reduce the labor share. But I suspect (hope) that it may contribute to reduced inequality
column8: Perhaps four-year college degrees won't appear so damn relevant to every well-paid occupation in industrialized economies. That would be a good thing.
column11: I think it's slightly more likely to do the opposite.

column5: The highest skilled workers will benefit from it. The medium skilled ones will be displaced

column11: It might benefit different groups than the current high earners and hence might contribute to social mobility.

column8: I imagine that specialized educational programs for particular professions could have more uncertain returns.
column11: It is plausible that it could decrease income inequality.

column5: Answer may depend upon meaning of high skill. Sufficiently high skill may be immune.
Uncertain.  Spreadsheets did not reduce the demand for analysts / investment bankers.  Demand increased.
some for sure, but net effects including new options created is harder to judge.
Hard to predict the mix of automation versus augmentation
column8: AI is improving rapidly at many skills we teach in higher education: synthesizing and distilling information, writing, coding, analytical and quantitative reasoning. Difficult to foresee all the implications, but they will be substantial.

column5: Like all major new technologies, it will be disruptive. It may be more rapid than earlier changes given the speed of diffusion in the electronic age. But whether it will be a large fraction or relative minor, not clear.
column8: Do not see it as reducing the returns to education, but is likely to be highly disruptive in that sector. Probabiy increases the uncertainty about the structure of education, but then so did Google for libraries.
column11: I think the impact on aggregate economic factors for the next decade is exaggerated.

column5: AI may depress the earnings of many highly skilled workers, but may also open new opportunities for high-skill, high-earnings jobs.
column8: AI may well make education all the more important.

column5: The implementation of AI will probably be slower than the hype indicates.  So it will probably take more time to affect a large number of high skilled workers.

column11: Much to early to predict the outcomes of the many decisions involved.

column5: A negative impact on some specialities; positive on others. This is a disruptive technology.
column8: The return to education overall will likely rise substantially, but there will be reductions in returns for many specialized subjects
